content.question: A spherical snowball is melting in such a way that it maintains its shape. The volume of the snowball is decreasing at a constant rate of <math alttext="5" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>5</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> cubic inches per minute. At the instant when the radius of the snowball is decreasing at a rate of <math alttext="three fifths" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mfrac><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>5</mn></mrow></mfrac></mrow></mstyle></math> inch per minute, what is the radius of the snowball, in inches? (The volume <math alttext="V" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>V</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> of a sphere with radius <math alttext="r" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>r</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is <math alttext="V equals, four thirds pi times r cubed" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mi>V</mi><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><mn>4</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></mfrac><mi>π</mi><msup><mrow><mi>r</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msup></mrow></math>.)
